subject: Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... Perhaps more important is preventing me from writing Tea-Awe-Tea for tot while Tea-Ox-Tea for taught which reading the QM with no outside material
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:

>
> So the question is, do I just put up with it when you write "awed" as
> Ah-Day, or do I insist that you artificially learn to write Awe-Day,
> which is natural for me and most people outside the U.S. west of the
> Missisippi and Canada west of Quebec? That's the policy choice facing
> the QS community.

Perhaps more important is preventing me from writing Tea-Awe-Tea for
"tot" while Tea-Ox-Tea for "taught" which reading the QM with no
outside material would let me do.


>
> But if QS letters mean the same *sounds* everywhere, then instead of
> everyone everywhere (near enough) writing At-Key-See-Et-No-Tea for
> "accent", we must put up with It-Key-See-Et-No-Tea from New Zealand and
> Eight-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea (or even Eight-Utter-Key-See-Utter-No-Tea)
> from the Inland Northern U.S. I think that's intolerable.
>

But surely this is unavoidable isn't it? I suppose it can be
moderated some but surely there is no conceivable way to assign
phonemes or any other abstract entity to QS letters such that all
speakers everywhere spell all words the same. What possible
description of #29 would allow a west coast US accent to use it for
both "eight" and "pair" as is done in Received Pronunciation English
and not use #29 in words RP does not?
And what possible description of #32, #33 and #34 could be given
such that I use them as an RP speaker would?
That reading text with varied spelling is a bit slower is not the
end of the world. Elizabethan England functioned adequately I think.
And the bulk of a person's communication is normally done with people
of his own accent in which case there would be no variation. And
besides that, a critical set of very common words are standardized in
QS which would reduce this inefficiency further.
